column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Song
#Text=In every heart to find a Slave , In every Soul to fix his reign , In bonds to lead the wise and brave , And make the Captives kiss his chain , Such is the power of Love , and Oh !
#Text=I grieve so well Love 's power to know .
#Text=In sighs to pass the live-long day , To taste a short and broken sleep , For one dear Object far away , All others scorned , to watch and weep , Such are the pains of Love , and Oh !
#Text=I grieve so well Love 's pains to know !
#Text=To read consent in virgin eyes , To press the lip ne'er prest till then To hear the sigh of transport rise , And kiss , and kiss , and kiss again , Such are thy pleasures , Love , But Oh !
#Text=When shall my heart thy pleasures know ?
#Text=Chorus
#Text=Now hush , my Lyre !
#Text=My voice be still !
#Text=Sleep , gentle Maid !
#Text=May fond desire With amorous thoughts thy visions fill , Though still my voice , and hushed my Lyre .
#Text=The Music ceased : The Performers dispersed , and silence prevailed through the Street .
#Text=Antonia quitted the window with regret : She as usual recommended herself to the protection of St. Rosolia , said her accustomed prayers , and retired to bed .
#Text=Sleep was not long absent , and his presence relieved her from her terrors and inquietude .
#Text=It was almost two o'clock before the lustful Monk ventured to bend his steps towards Antonia 's dwelling .
#Text=It has been already mentioned that the Abbey was at no great distance from the Strada di San Iago .
#Text=He reached the House unobserved .
#Text=Here
#Text=He stopped , and hesitated for a moment .
#Text=He reflected on the enormity of the crime , the consequences of a discovery , and the probability , after what had passed , of Elvira 's suspecting him to be her Daughter 's Ravisher :

#Text=On the other hand it was suggested that She could do no more than suspect ; that no proofs of his guilt could be produced ; that it would seem impossible for the rape to have been committed without Antonia 's knowing when , where , or by whom ; and finally , He believed that his fame was too firmly established to be shaken by the unsupported accusations of two unknown Women .

#Text=This latter argument was perfectly false : He knew not how uncertain is the air of popular applause , and that a moment suffices to make him today the detestation of the world , who yesterday was its Idol .
#Text=The result of the Monk 's deliberations was that He should proceed in his enterprize .
#Text=He ascended the steps leading to the House .
#Text=No sooner did He touch the door with the silver Myrtle , than it flew open , and presented him with a free passage .
#Text=He entered , and the door closed after him of its own accord .
#Text=Guided by the moonbeams , He proceeded up the Staircase with slow and cautious steps .
#Text=He looked round him every moment with apprehension and anxiety .
#Text=He saw a Spy in every shadow , and heard a voice in every murmur of the night breeze .
#Text=Consciousness of the guilty business on which He was employed appalled his heart , and rendered it more timid than a Woman 's .
#Text=Yet still He proceeded .
#Text=He reached the door of Antonia 's chamber .
#Text=He stopped , and listened .
#Text=All was hushed within .
#Text=The total silence persuaded him that his intended Victim was retired to rest , and He ventured to lift up the Latch .
#Text=The door was fastened , and resisted his efforts : But no sooner was it touched by the Talisman , than the Bolt flew back .
#Text=The Ravisher stept on , and found himself in the chamber , where slept the innocent Girl , unconscious how dangerous a Visitor was drawing near her Couch .
#Text=The door closed after him , and the Bolt shot again into its fastening .
#Text=Ambrosio advanced with precaution .
#Text=He took care that not a board should creak under his foot , and held in his breath as He approached the Bed .

#Text=His first attention was to perform the magic ceremony , as Matilda had charged him : He breathed thrice upon the silver Myrtle , pronounced over it Antonia 's name , and laid it upon her pillow .
#Text=The effects which it had already produced permitted not his doubting its success in prolonging the slumbers of his devoted Mistress .
#Text=No sooner was the enchantment performed than He considered her to be absolutely in his power , and his eyes flamed with lust and impatience .
#Text=He now ventured to cast a glance upon the sleeping Beauty .
#Text=A single Lamp , burning before the Statue of St. Rosolia , shed a faint light through the room , and permitted him to examine all the charms of the lovely Object before him .
#Text=The heat of the weather had obliged her to throw off part of the Bed-cloathes :
#Text=Those which still covered her , Ambrosio 's insolent hand hastened to remove .
#Text=She lay with her cheek reclining upon one ivory arm ; The Other rested on the side of the Bed with graceful indolence .
#Text=A few tresses of her hair had escaped from beneath the Muslin which confined the rest , and fell carelessly over her bosom , as it heaved with slow and regular suspiration .
#Text=The warm air had spread her cheek with higher colour than usual .
#Text=A smile inexpressibly sweet played round her ripe and coral lips , from which every now and then escaped a gentle sigh or an half-pronounced sentence .
#Text=An air of enchanting innocence and candour pervaded her whole form ; and there was a sort of modesty in her very nakedness which added fresh stings to the desires of the lustful Monk .
